Course Description: THIS COURSE PROVIDES AN OVERVIEW OF ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE APPLICATIONS IN BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS. THE STUDENT WILL PROGRESSIVELY WORK THROUGH AN ACCOUNTING CYCLE FOR A BUSINESS USING POPULAR ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE. SPECIFIC APPLICATIONS WILL INCLUDE THE DESIGN AND SETUP OF AN ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEM FOR A NEW COMPANY, RECORDING ACCOUNTING TRANSACTIONS, AND THE CREATION AND ANALYSIS OF VARIOUS REPORTS AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS. TRANSACTIONAL AND REPORTING AREAS WILL INCLUDE BANKING, CUSTOMERS, SALES, VENDORS, PURCHASES, INVENTORY, EMPLOYEES, AND PAYROLL. THE COURSE IS TAUGHT USING QUICKBOOKS ONLINE ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE AND WILL PREPARE STUDENTS TO SIT FOR THE INTUIT QUICKBOOKS CERTIFIED USER EXAMINATION FOR QUICKBOOKS ONLINE.  45 CLASS HOURS.
Objectives / Learning Outcome(s) / Major:
COURSE OBJECTIVES:   

1.	THE STUDENT WILL BE ABLE TO UTILIZE KNOWLEDGE OF THE IMPORTANCE OF MICROCOMPUTERS IN ACCOUNTING. 
A.	LIST AND EXPLAIN THE BASIC HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE COMPONENTS NEEDED FOR A MICROCOMPUTER ACCOUNTING SYSTEM. 
B.	EXPLAIN THE PRACTICAL GUIDELINES FOR PURCHASING ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE, MAKING CONVERSIONS TO THE NEW SOFTWARE AND ESTABLISHING CONTROLS. 
C.	EXPLAIN THE DIFFERENCES AND SIMILARITIES BETWEEN A MANUAL ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEM AND A COMPUTERIZED ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEM. 

2.	THE STUDENT WILL BE ABLE TO UTILIZE KNOWLEDGE OF MICROCOMPUTER ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE. 
A.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO PROPERLY DESIGN THE ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEM OF A NEW OR EXISTING BUSINESS.  
B.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO RECORD ACCOUNTING TRANSACTIONS PROPERLY ACCORDING TO SPECIFIC ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE APPLICATION INSTRUCTIONS.  
C.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO POST ACCOUNTING TRANSACTIONS TO ACCOUNTS IN THE GENERAL LEDGER AND SUBSIDIARY LEDGERS. 
D.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO PREPARE A GENERAL JOURNAL, GENERAL LEDGER, TRIAL BALANCE, AND OTHER INFORMATIONAL SCHEDULES COMMON TO ACCOUNTANTS AND BUSINESS. 
E.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO PREPARE AND ENTER APPROPRIATE ADJUSTING JOURNAL ENTRIES. 
F.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO PREPARE A PAYROLL FOR A SERIES OF PAY PERIODS INCLUDING THE PREPARATION OF (A) PAYROLL REGISTER, (B) INDIVIDUAL EARNINGS, AND (C) PAY CHECKS. 
G.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO COMPLETE QUARTERLY AND ANNUAL FEDERAL PAYROLL TAX RETURNS INCLUDING (A) FORM 941 AND (B) FORM 940. 
H.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO ENTER SALES AND PURCHASE ACCOUNTING TRANSACTIONS LEADING TO PROPER ENTRIES AND OPERATION OF A PERPETUAL INVENTORY SYSTEM
I.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO OPERATE VARIOUS AUXILIARY ACCOUNTING MODULES INCLUDING BANKING, CUSTOMERS, SALES, VENDORS, PURCHASES, INVENTORY, EMPLOYEES, JOB COST CENTERS, ORDER PROCESSING, INSURANCE, AND DEPRECIATION.
J.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO MAINTAIN PROPERTY, PLANT, AND EQUIPMENT ACCOUNTING RECORDS INCLUDING PURCHASES AND DISPOSITIONS.  
K.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO PROPERLY CLOSE THE ACCOUNTING RECORDS AT THE END OF AN ACCOUNTING PERIOD.  

3.	STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO UTILIZE KNOWLEDGE OF MICROCOMPUTER ACCOUNTING SOFTWARE IN PREPARING REPORTS AND MAKING BUSINESS DECISIONS. 
A.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO PREPARE AND PRINT THE FOUR BASIC FINANCIAL STATEMENTS IN ACCORDANCE WITH GENERALLY ACCEPTED ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES (GAAP). 
B.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO USE RESEARCH TECHNIQUES TO FIND DETAILED ACCOUNTING INFORMATION WITHIN THE COMPUTERIZED ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEM. 
C.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO EXAMINE ALL REPORTS AND MAKE NECESSARY CORRECTIONS. 
D.	DEMONSTRATE THE ABILITY TO OPERATE VARIOUS AUXILIARY ACCOUNTING MODULES IN APPLYING FINANCIAL STATEMENT ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES.
